block.p: International

The Japanese stock market improved marginally today amid a tense atmosphere. Analysts said most players appeared to be watching for what, if anything, the Government would do to try to arrest the steady erosion in investor confidence. [ Page D1. ] Companies

Robert J. Eaton, who was named to replace Lee A. Iacocca when the chairman and chief executive of Chrysler retires at the end of the year, gives up a 29-year career at General Motors and takes his biggest risk yet in joining the No. 3 U.S. auto maker. [ D1. ]
International

The Japanese stock market improved marginally today amid a tense atmosphere. Analysts said most players appeared to be watching for what, if anything, the Government would do to try to arrest the steady erosion in investor confidence. [ Page D1. ] Companies

Robert J. Eaton, who was named to replace Lee A. Iacocca when the chairman and chief executive of Chrysler retires at the end of the year, gives up a 29-year career at General Motors and takes his biggest risk yet in joining the No. 3 U.S. auto maker. [ D1. ]
Mr. Eaton was named Chrysler's chief operating officer and will join Mr. Iacocca in a new office of the chief executive. Robert A. Lutz said he would remain as president. [ D5. ]
G.E. threatened to sue a whistle-blowing employee to recover any monetary award he receives for bringing forward charges of wrongdoing in its sale of military jet engines to Israel. [ D1. ]
Bell Atlantic plans a "one person, one number" service giving customers a single number in different locations. [ D1. ]
Braun, which has thrived outside Germany by melding distinctive designs with the marketing power of its parent, Gillette, is counting on new products and refinements of best sellers. [ D1. ]
Investcorp, a New-York investment bank, emerged as the leader of a group that has offered $425 million to buy the Circle K Corporation, the bankrupt convenience store chain. [ D2. ]
Pfizer is negotiating to sell its Coty perfume and cosmetics unit to a German company for a reported $475 million. [ D4. ]
Paramount Pictures was ordered to pay the columnist Art Buchwald $150,000 and his producing partner $750,000 for their contributions to the hit movie "Coming to America." [ C13. ] The Economy
The decision of the Taystee Bakery to move from Queens to Pennsylvania poses a classic question: How far should the city go to subsidize manufacturers to keep jobs in New York City? [ A1. ]
Public pension funds in many states are being urged by elected officials to invest in local businesses, housing and other ventures in to bolster the economy. [ D1. ]
The Justice Department has told the White House that registered lobbyists for foreign governments and corporations can not serve on Federal advisory panels. [ D21. ]
A new study concludes that spending billions to reduce carbon dioxide emissions would save consumers and industry $5 trillion in lower fuel and electricity bills. [ C1. ] Markets
Stocks ended mixed in lethargic trading. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 0.45 point, to 3,236.36. [ D8. ]
Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed in fairly active trading. Market sentiment remained very negative. [ D21. ]
Gold dropped to its lowest price in more than five and a half years, falling $3.40 an ounce, to $343.30, on the spot market. [ D22. ] The dollar was marginally lower. [ D22. ] Today's Columns
Employers and retirees could save millions of dollars because of new rules that limit what doctors in the Medicare program can charge. Milt Freudenheim: Business and Health. [ D2. ]
The plunge in Tokyo's blue-chip stocks made one issue clear: Japan has become the make-or-break bet this year for many money managers and investors. Market Place. [ D8. ]
G.M. last changed one of its advertising agencies in 1958. It supports the long-term policy. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [ D23. ]
